It is possible for scale crawlers to be wind blown into orchards from adjacent hedgerows, wooded borders, or orchards. Within one day after emerging, crawlers settle, insert their mouthparts into a host, and begin to feed. Within two to three days of settling, crawlers begin to secrete their protective coating. There are four or more generations of San Jose scale per year in much of the southeast. San Jose scale has a very high reproductive potential. Serious infestations can develop between harvest and the onset of winter. This is especially true when abundant late-summer rainfall promotes succulent growth favorable for scale development.
chemical:
Trees and fruit should be inspected frequently for the presence of scale insects. Scales blend in well with peach bark and are generally hard to see. Controls are suggested when scale lesions were present on fruit the previous year or when scales are found on wood during pruning. Mark heavily infested trees so you can readily monitor scale development. Pruning out infested branches or suckers can modestly reduce scale abundance. Careful tree training also opens the canopy, which facilitates better spray coverage.

The most common and effective scale control options are two oil applications made during dormancy to kill overwintering scales. Complete coverage with dilute sprays is critical because the oil must coat the scales to kill them. Further in-season scale management is achieved by insecticide sprays targeting the first crawler generation in May. In mid-March, place a San Jose scale pheromone trap in the upper half of each of three scale-infested trees. Monitor traps for male capture twice weekly. Once you notice captured males, begin accumulating degree-days (developmental base of 51oF). Crawler emergence occurs 400 to 700 degree-days after initiation of male emergence (early May). Wrap scale-infested branches with double-sided sticky tape (or black electrical tape coated with petroleum jelly) and check tape for scale crawlers twice per week. Spray insecticide promptly when the yellow crawlers appear on the tape and continue sprays every 10 days until no crawlers are captured (usually two sprays are adequate). These sprays should be applied with sufficient volume to wet the wood. In some cases where heavy infestations exist, post-harvest applications may be required and repeated for several years.
fungicide: Resistance to diazinon and chlorpyrifos have been documented in populations in California, and such cases carbaryl worked as an alternative. Rotate chemicals with different mode-of-action Group numbers, and do not use products with the same mode-of-action Group number more than twice per season to help prevent the development of resistance.
biological: Destruction of nearby alternative hosts, such as plum, abandoned peach blocks, and other alternate hosts may reduce immigration of scale into the orchard. Burning and proper disposal of removed trees and limbs infested with scale is also important.

name: Caterpillars, cabbage looper (Trichoplusia ni), beet armyworm (Spodoptera exigua), cutworm (noctuiid moths), strawberry leaf roller (Ancylis comptana), leaf tier (Cnephasia longana), corn earworm (H
chemical: In many cases caterpillar pests in strawberries do not require chemical treatment. Proper identification and scouting are critical to determining the need for an insecticide application. There are many conventional insecticides that effectively control caterpillars and also some organic options. Refer to the Southern Region Small Fruit Consortium Strawberry IPM Guide for regional recommendations.
fungicide: None.
biological: Cutworms are more of a problem in matted-row culture or weedy plantings. Control weeds to reduce the risk of cutworm infestation.

name: Leafhoppers: Primarily Homalodisca coagulata (Say), Oncometopia orbona (Fabr.), and Graphocephala versuta (Say)
symptoms:
Also known as sharpshooters, these insects are slender, elongate insects with round or pointed heads. The forewings are slightly thickened and frequently are held roof-like over the abdomen. Leafhoppers, particularly the glassy-winged sharpshooter, broad-headed sharpshooter, and redbanded leafhopper can vector several plant diseases, including phony peach disease. Leafhoppers are abundant insects and they are very strong fliers and readily move in and out of orchards.

Symptoms and Signs:
Direct leafhopper injury to peaches and other stone fruit is insignificant. Leafhoppers inject saliva and suck plant juices while feeding. All important leafhopper species on peach are stem feeders that have specialized to feed on the nutrient-poor xylem fluid, likely because of the near absence of plant defensive components in xylem fluid. The glassy-winged sharpshooter is a key vector of phony peach disease (Xylella fastidiosa) and plum leaf scald. It feeds on a variety of woody and herbaceous host plants. Plums and crape myrtle, are favorite summer hosts. Sharpshooters feed very selectively, moving from tree-to-tree or to-and-from orchards in response to xylem nutrients. On peach, leafhoppers feed selectively and aggressively during May and June when concentrations of key amino acids are highest. Leafhoppers aggregate on healthy, uninfected trees, but once infected, amino acid levels lessen causing these trees to become unattractive to leafhoppers.

Infected trees are more compact, leafier, and darker green than normal trees because of short-internodes. The number and size of fruit are drastically reduced. Phony peach disease can be a key factor in premature orchard decline and limit fruit production. Removal of phony trees is recommended primarily to remove unproductive, weed trees. Root suckers from infected trees that have been cut are very attractive to leafhoppers.
chemical: Insecticides applied to peaches targetting other pests throughout the season probably reduce leafhopper populations. However, because of the leafhoppers’ mobility, broad host ranges, and abundance on a variety of host plants, insecticidal control is impractical as a means of suppressing spread of phony peach disease.
fungicide: Leafhopper resistance to insecticides has occurred in the past, but no resistance has not been documented at this time for the three leafhopper species discussed here.
biological:
Cultural practices, such as orchard floor management and sucker removal, are the best means of reducing leafhopper populations in peach orchards. Keep orchard floor vegetation short and suppress broadleaf weeds and strong-stemmed, upright grasses such as johnsongrass and Texas panicum are recommended.

Additionally, remove succulent green peach suckers, as they frequently attract large numbers of leafhoppers. Although phony infected trees are less attractive to leafhoppers, vigorous sucker growth is quite attractive to leafhoppers and may create an important source of infection, thus removal of phony infected trees each year is recommended. It is also helpful to remove or kill all wild plums within 300 yards of orchards; within one-half mile if possible. Plums are a favored host for both the phony peach organism and its leafhopper vectors. Plums serve as a constant reservoir of infection for nearby peaches.

name: Brown marmorated stink bug: Halyomorpha halys (Stal)
symptoms:
Life cycle and injuries:
The brown marmorated stink bug overwintering adults emerge from their winter hideouts in early spring to mid-June and immediately feed on various available plants. The feeding of BMSB adults and nymphs is reported from close to 300 host plants. BMSB ability to survive and reproduce on various plants and unrestricted movement among various hosts is one of the main factors contributing to the continuous and quite unpredictable presence of this pest in orchards. If BMSB adults are not controlled during the early part of the season (May-June), and allowed to establish in the orchard, they become resident pest potentially causing injuries during the entire season. However, frequently BMSB adults are moving to orchards only during the late part of the season, especially in late August and September. Feeding damage on fruit caused by BMSB can occur throughout most of the season. Although the mechanism of BMSB feeding is similar during various parts of the season, the injury caused by stink bugs can have various appearances based on the time of the season the feeding takes place. Early feeding injury can result in misshapen fruit, while late season feeding on maturing fruit can cause the formation of necrotic tissue (corking) close to the skin surface. Sometime stink bug injuries on fruit can be confused with the physiological disorder called “corking” caused by calcium deficiency. Both, immatures and adults BMSB can cause the injuries. Initially, it can be very difficult to spot the injuries caused by the BMSB, as it takes up to 14 days for the symptoms to appear on the fruit surface. Brown marmorated stink bug adults are frequently reported as a nuisance to homeowners as they tended to overwinter inside houses and other dwellings.
Monitoring:
Visual observations and monitoring traps baited with BMSB aggregation pheromone are the most effective tools to monitor the occurrence of brown marmorated stink bug adults and nymphs. Commercial traps and lures for BMSB monitoring are available for purchase and should be placed in orchards at the beginning of the season. Although traps by themselves will not control BMSB, by capturing adults and nymphs, traps can be utilized as an early warning system. With a constant threat of new BMSB adults migrating into the orchard from surrounding vegetation such as woods or field crops, monitoring traps are the most practical tools to detect the presence of this pest.
chemical:
Chemical control:
Insecticides with various modes of action can effectively control the brown marmorated stink bug. While a number of commonly used products are effective against this pest (e.g., neonicotinoids, carbamates, or pyrethroids), the continuous challenge revolves around the unrestricted influx of new stink bug adults from surrounding vegetation and therefore causes the necessity of multiple, repeated applications of insecticides. Pyrethroids and carbamates are very toxic to beneficial insects and frequent use of these products can lead to the severe outbreaks of secondary pests such as mites, aphids and scales.
fungicide: As of spring 2017, no documented instances of insecticide resistance are known to exist among BMSB populations, however, differences in BMSB sensitivity to various compounds within the same IRAC group such as pyrethroids (IRAC Group 3A) or neonicotinoids (IRAC Group 4A) are frequently observed. Please see the list of recommended products under “Active ingredients” in this application.
biological: The native biological control agents are not effective in controlling BMSB. Although some biological control provided by generalist predators, parasitoids or birds is possible, in commercial agricultural setting such control is frequently not sufficient and targeted applications of insecticides are necessary. No other alternative methods to manage BMSB are currently available.

name: Codling moth: Cydia pomonella (L.)
symptoms:
Life cycle and injuries:
Codling moth overwinters as full-grown larvae within a cocoon usually within loose bark scales, or any other sheltered place. Pupation occurs around pink stage on apples, with first flight occurring about full bloom, and flight lasting 2 to 10 weeks after full bloom. First-generation eggs hatch in about 6 to 10 days. Newly hatched larvae bore through the fruit surface, and continue tunneling to the core. Larvae feed on the seeds and surrounding flesh until they are fully grown in 3 to 4 weeks. The larvae have a cream to pinkish body and a brown head with dark speckles on the prothoracic shield behind the head. Larvae reach to 5∕8 inch long at maturity. The second generation adults emerge about two weeks later and produce next generation of larvae. Some second generation larvae may also pupate and produce a third generation adults.
Damage to apples may be shown either by a tunnel emanating from the apple side or calyx and extending to the core, or by “stings,” small shallow holes the size of pin pricks, with a little dead tissue on the cavity walls. Stings are caused by early instar larvae that have been poisoned and die shortly after puncturing the apple skin. Larvae that feed on the core characteristically leave frass exuding from the point of entry. Codling moth larvae are often confused with the Oriental fruit moth larvae, which are smaller, lack spots on the prothoracic shield, and have a comblike structure (anal comb) on the posterior end visible under magnification.
Monitoring:
Pheromone traps for monitoring codling moth should be placed at a density of at least one trap per 5 acres by the pink stage and situated on the outside of the tree, preferably in the upper fourth of the canopy. The higher the trap placement, the better codling moth is monitored. In the spring, traps should be checked daily until the first adult is caught to set biofix for phenology models using degree-day accumulations and then weekly thereafter. In orchards implementing mating disruption for codling moth control, monitoring should be done using special CM DA Combo (CM DAC) lures.
chemical:
In orchards without codling moth mating disruption, if the action threshold of five moths per trap per week is exceeded an insecticide application should be made within 5 to 8 days. Repeat applications should be made if the number of captured moths exceeds this threshold 14 days after the insecticide application.
Optimum timing of insecticide applications based on egg hatch can be determined with the aid of a degree-day model. The first insecticide application should be made at 250–350 degree-days (base 500F) after the first capture of males in the sex pheromone traps. A second application can be applied 14 to 21 days following the initial application if needed. If insecticides with ovicidal activity are planned for codling moth control, the first application should be performed no later than at about 150 DD after the biofix. Due to frequently extended codling moth flight observed in many orchards, additional insecticide treatments may be necessary after the second application. The control of the second CM generation should be initiated at 1250 DD base 500F.
fungicide: Codling moth significance as an apple pest increased significantly during the last 10 years mainly due to the insecticide resistance. Codling moth has been known to infest up to 95 percent of the apples in an orchard when control measures were not taken against it. Insecticide resistance and cross-resistance in some codling moth populations was documented when treated with various organophosphate (IRAC Group 1B), carbamate (IRAC Group 1A) and pyrethroid (IRAC Group 3A) insecticides.
biological: Mating disruption represents a valuable alternative to insecticide treatments for isolated orchards with a low codling moth population. The hand-applied pheromone dispensers and various forms of sprayable pheromones are commercially available and can be used for codling moth control. If Oriental fruit moth is also a problem in the same block, then Isomate CM/OFM CTT or CheckMate Puffer CM-OFM Pro should be used for the control of both species. A combination of mating disruption and codling moth granulosis virus is recommended to effectively control this pest. Also, the recently registered insecticides with new modes of action such as Altacor or Delegate are very effective against this pest.

name: Oriental Fruit Moth (OFM): Grapholita molesta (Busck)
symptoms:
Symptoms and Signs:
The means of damage from OFM is through young twig boring and boring into fruit. OFM larvae enter young succulent twigs via the leaf axil nearest the terminal, and bore down up to 6-inches into the twig. This can effectively kill the twig, ceasing growth, causing the twig to droop and discolor (‘flagging’) – eventually killing the limb. In fruit, the moth larvae enter through a tiny hole it bores, and proceeds to excavate tunnels through the fruit to the pit. Fruit damage from OFM, while less common than twig damage, renders the fruit unconsumable.

Insect Life Cycle:
OFM have, on average, 6 generations per year in the Southeast. The first generation overwinters as larvae in silken cocoons within twigs or fruit on the ground, or directly on the tree. This generation typically emerges before peach bloom, and continues for several weeks thereafter. Upon emerging, the adults mate, and females lay eggs on the underside of leaves near the tips of twigs. This second generation hatches and bores into vegative twigs (through the first leaf axil of the twig), and develops within two to eight weeks thereafter. The cycle continues through the season, with the female beginning to lay her (up to) 200 eggs 2-5 days after she emerges.
chemical: The primary means of chemical control is an application of organophosphates (phosmet; Imidan) or pyrethroids (beta cyfluthrin, cyfluthrin, gamma and lambda cyhalothrin, etc.) to control the first generation of OFM. If this application is timed correctly, and properly applied, then subsequent generational pest issues from OFM should be at a minimum (if adjacent or nearby orchards without proper control measures are not reinfesting the orchard). If later OFM pressure is noted (which is rare is the Southeast), additional applications of organophosphates (phosmet; Imidan) or neonicotinoids (thiamethoxam, clothianidin; Actara, Belay) may be necessary.
fungicide: Resistance has not been documented at this time. However, consistent rotation with pesticides used for this pest will help avoid any resistance, especially in the resistance-prone pesticide pyrethroid class.
biological:
Use of pheromone trapping (to determine proper spray timing) and mating disruption are methods controlling OFM through reduced (or no) insecticide usage. In the first, three pheromone traps are placed per orchard, and monitored until 5 moths per trap are collected, prompting an application of pesticide.

In mating disruption, mating pheromones (those produced by the female to attract males) are released in high rates via mating disruption dispensers (100/acre) within the orchard. This floods the orchard with mating pheromones, making it nearly impossible for males to locate potential mates amidst the onslaught of chemical cues.

name: Aphids, Strawberry aphid (Chaetosiphon fragaefolii), Green peach aphid (Myzus persicae),Melon aphid (Aphis gossypii), Potato aphid (Macrosiphum euphorbiae)
symptoms: Aphid damage typically appears as small yellow leaf spots and downward curved, wrinkled leaves. A black sooty mold may form on the honeydew secreted by the aphids. Aphids can usually be found on leaves showing symptoms.
chemical: Chemical control is rarely necessary for aphid management. Do not apply sprays unless populations are very high and exceed thresholds or if excessive sooty mold is present. Consult your local Cooperative Extension professional for thresholds in your area.
fungicide: Resistance to insecticides is not commonly reported in aphids, but has occurred in some species found on strawberry.
biological: Natural biological control present in the field is usually sufficient for aphid management. This includes natural enemies like lacewings, ladybeetles, hoverfly (syrphid) larvae, and parasitoid wasps.

name: Plum Curculio Conotrachelus nenuphar
chemical:
Begin Surround applications at the onset of petal fall and continue to reapply weekly to maintain coverage and deter egg laying.  Surround is an organically approved material that can also be complementary to conventional management strategies.  Do not apply insecticides until bloom is completely finished to reduce unwanted pollinator exposure.  When using pre-mixes, ensure the modes of action in the material are effective against more than one of the pests you are managing.  For example a petal fall spray of Voliam Flexi will be effective against both plum curculio and european apple sawfly.  This material has moderate toxicity for honeybees and low toxicity to some predatory insects (not too shabby).
For infromation on rainfast characteristics of some insecticides, see the following article in Fruit Grower’s News: http://fruitgrowersnews.com/news/rainfast-characteristics-insecticides-fruit-reviewed/
fungicide: Not at this time, however, rotating materials should always be practiced to avoid development of resistance in the future.

name: Twospotted spider mite Tetranychus urticae
chemical: Summer applications of miticides are indicated when thresholds are met or damage is evident. Early season oil applications are not particularly effective.
fungicide: Resistance is likely when miticides are not rotated. Be sure to rotate miticide classes when choosing chemical control.
biological:
Minimize weed growth, particularly broadleaf weeds, in the orchard. Mow frequently to keep groundcover short, but avoid mowing during hot/dry spells.

Adapted from Extension Bulletin E154 “2015 Michigan Fruit Management Guide for Commercial Fruit Growers” https://shop.msu.edu/product_p/bulletin-e0154.htm

name: Pear Psylla Cacopsylla pyricola
chemical: Start with oil sprays in early spring, then beginning at bud break use insecticides with good-excellent efficacy against pear psylla. Focus on early season management to keep psylla from becoming a season-long problem. Low rate oil applications can be used in addition to insecticide applications (watch the timing of this with critical temperatures and oil containing product application).  Pyrethroids (Asana, Brigade, Danitol, Warrior) are good choices early unless resistance is suspected. Esteem, an IGR, has to be applied at white bud stage then again at petal fall. 14-days after petal fall, Agri-Mek plus oil should give season-long control. Neonics (Admire, Actara, Clutch, Assail), Proclaim, and Portal require two or more applications for adequate control. Centaur and Movento when applied at the correct timing (nymph hatch) give good control of psylla. Neem compounds ( Aza-Direct and Ecozin 3% EC) require multiple applications to suppress pear psylla. And Surround is effective to deter egg laying by adults and nymph feeding, but multiple applications and complete coverage are necessary.
fungicide: YES! Pear psylla has become quite resistant to conventional insecticides (pyrethroids). Difficulty controlling psylla with these indicates you have a resistance issue, and you need to try some of the newer chemistries/registrations. Be sure to rotate active ingredients (use the IRAC codes listed in this app. to help!) to prevent/delay resistance development. Oil and Surround are good applications too.  These will not bring on resistance issues.
biological:
Avoid excessive, succulent shoot growth by cutting back on pruning and nitrogen fertilization. Prune after bloom if possible. Summer prune to remove water sprouts.

Adapted from Extension Bulletin E154 “2015 Michigan Fruit Management Guide for Commercial Fruit Growers” https://shop.msu.edu/product_p/bulletin-e0154.htm

name: Speckled green fruitworm Orthosia hibisci
chemical: Use of broad-spectrum or selective (e.g., Bacillus thuringiensis) insecticides, if necessary, before or after bloom.
fungicide: None documented. As always, rotate insecticide modes of action when possible.
biological: B.t. sprays are effective at managing green fruitworm(s).

name: Codling Moth Cydia pomonella
chemical:
When using mating disruption, it is critical to deploy prior to adult emergence.  Mating disruption is most effective in larger plantings (~5 acres +). Granulosis virus (Cyd-X, etc.) is effective against larvae only as it must be ingested for infection to occur.  Make first applications of granulovirus ~250 DD after biofix (first adult capture) for treatment of first generation.    

Adapted from ‘Common Tree Fruit Pests,’ Angus Howitt, Michigan State University, 1993.  ‘Compendium of Apple and Pear Disease and Pests, 2nd Addition’ Sutton, et. al. APS Press 2014.
fungicide: Resistance to organophosphates has been documented in some regions of Washington and Oregon, and is likely to occur elsewhere.
biological: Remove abandoned orchards and other alternate hosts, where practicable. Trunk banding can be a useful method of reducing codling moth pressure. Cardboard wrapped around trunks before larvae move to cocooning sites will cause them to pupate on the cardboard, which is subsequently removed and destroyed prior to adult emergence. Hot water treatment of storage bins can destroy a number of the overwintering larvae.  Mating disruption and Surround are also effective non-chemical control methods.

name: Stink bugs
symptoms:
Stink Bugs: Common southern stink bugs are:
Brown Stink Bug: Euschistus servus (Say), is a native stink bug, and is usually the most common stink bug found in peach orchards in the South. It is roughly ½ inch in length, and typically has pointed ends on the ‘shoulders.’ They are light-grayish to dark-brown in overall color, with dark-brown or black markings sprinkled throughout.
Green Stink Bug: Acrosternum hilare (Say), is a native stink bug species, roughly ½ an inch in length. The adults are pale- to lime-green in coloration, sometimes with stripes or banding of light brown or reddish-brown. On the underside of the abdomen, Green stink bugs have a distinctive point on the first segment after the hind legs.
Southern Green Stink Bug: Nezara viridula (Linnaeus), is a native species, roughly the same size and appearance as the green stink bug. Notable differences between the two are in coloration (southern green stink bugs are always uniform lime- or light-green, with no line or banding), and the first segment after the hind legs under the abdomen is rounded rather than pointed.
Red-shouldered Stink Bug: Thyantaspecies, are similarly colored as other green stink bugs, but many species also possess vivid red markings on the thorax and abdomen – often most obvious on the edge of the thorax next to the head. They tend to be smaller than other common stink bug pest species, about 3/8than inch in length.

Sucking bugs overwinter as adults, usually in debris on the ground or in sheltered places (under bark, branch/twig nooks, under material on the ground, debris piles, in human structures, etc.). The emergence period differs between species, sometimes staggered even within species, but tends to be in early-spring. 

Stink bugs can occur and feed anytime through the year in the Southeast, and have even been to become active on warm days in winter. The first of the primary peach feeding stink bugs to emerge and begin feeding are the red-shouldered stink bugs. They are known to be present and feeding beginning late-bloom, with most leaving for other hosts within a month after shuck-fall. The brown stink bug, the most commonly encountered stink bug in peaches, usually reach peak abundance about 6-weeks after shuck-fall, but can persist in high numbers through July. Greenand Southern green stink bugsare at their highest abundance after June, usually mid-July through August. Stink bugshave two or more generations per year, depending on the species and conditions. 

Symptoms and Signs: The feeding on leaf buds, flower buds, and blooms can cause the buds to wither and abort, failing to bloom. After petal fall, when tarnished plant bugsand stink bug numbers can precipitously increase, the feeding is mainly on young fruit. When feeding, the cells in the tissue surrounding the wound are destroyed. This causes scarring, which leads to ‘cat-facing’ injury as the fruit continues to grow and swell. Significant cat-facing damage can make the peach unmarketable. After pit hardening, most stink bug feeding doesn’t cause much scarring or distortion – but the fruit around feeding sites can become dry, corky, and/or slightly sunken areas in the peach.
chemical: Stink bugs are generally not a key of concern in managed peach orchards. However, if stink bugs and/or associated damage are observed to be increasing (principally through proper monitoring efforts, especially from pink through shuck split), applications of neonicotinoids (thiamethoxamor clothianidin; e.g. Actara or Belay) mixed with pyrethroids (beta-cyfluthrinor fenpropathrin; e.g. Baythroid or Danitol) beginning at shuck split is the most effective remedy. Additional applications after that initial treatment can be applied at 10- to 14-day intervals, if plant bug pressure warrants such action.
fungicide: None known.
biological: The foremost means of managing stink bugs is proper orchard floor maintenance and broadleaf weed suppression. Removal of broadleaf weeds, particularly white clover, will remove alternative hosts and a potential refuge for stink bugs.

name: Plant Bugs
symptoms:
Plant bugs are a large, diverse family of insects that typically feed on plant parts, including buds, flowers, and fruit. They feed by sucking sap from plants and can cause economically important damage at relatively low densities. The most common plant bug of concern is the tarnished plant bug (Lygus lineolaris). Adult tarnished plant bugs are bronze to dark brown insects, about ¼ inch long, oval in shape, with white marks and/or lines behind the head and sometimes along the front wing. The back half of the front wing is membranous and held at a downward angle. The hind wing is membranous, and not visible unless the insect is flying, or you pull back the front wing. Newly hatched nymphs are yellowish green and about 1/32 inch long. Older nymphs are yellowish-green to green, wingless, develop yellow, green, or black spots as they mature. Fourth and fifth stage nymphs have four black spots on the thorax and one on the abdomen.

Sucking bugs overwinter as adults, usually in debris on the ground or in sheltered places (under bark, branch/twig nooks, under material on the ground, debris piles, in human structures, etc.). The emergence period differs between species, sometimes staggered even within species, but tends to be in early-spring. Plant bugs in general are most abundant in Southern peach orchards from bud-break until about 8-weeks after bloom. The tarnished plant bug is active as soon as the weather is warm. They are usually present and feeding by the time buds begin to swell. Eggs are laid on tender-shoot and buds shortly after emergence, with nymphs hatching in about 5-7 days – though tarnished plant-bugs rarely lay eggs on peaches. There are five developmental nymphal instars (stages), and the whole life cycle from egg to adult can be as fast as three weeks. As such, there are several generations of tarnished plant-bugs every year. They tend to begin dispersing in search of alternative hosts after petal-fall, and are nearly absent in peaches by shuck fall.

Symptoms and Signs: The feeding on leaf buds, flower buds, and blooms can cause the buds to wither and abort, failing to bloom. After petal fall, when plant bug numbers can abruptly increase, the feeding is mainly on young fruit. When feeding, the cells in the tissue surrounding the wound are destroyed. This causes scarring, which leads to ‘cat-facing’ injury as the fruit continues to grow and swell. Significant cat-facing damage can make the peach unmarketable. After pit hardening, most stink bug feeding doesn’t cause much scarring or distortion – but the fruit around feeding sites can become dry, corky, and/or slightly sunken areas in the peach.
chemical: Plant bugs are generally not a key of concern in managed peach orchards. However, if plant bugs and/or associated damage are observed to be increasing (principally through proper monitoring efforts, especially from pink through shuck split), applications of neonicotinoids (thiamethoxamor clothianidin; e.g. Actara or Belay) mixed with pyrethroids (beta-cyfluthrinor fenpropathrin; e.g. Baythroid or Danitol) beginning at shuck split is the most effective remedy. Additional applications after that initial treatment can be applied at 10- to 14-day intervals, if plant bug pressure warrants such action.
fungicide: None known.
biological: The foremost means of managing plant bugs is proper orchard floor maintenance and broadleaf weed suppression. Removal of broadleaf weeds, particularly white clover, will remove alternative hosts and a potential refuge for plant bugs.

name: Black pecan aphid: Melanocallis caryaefoliae (Davis)
symptoms: None
chemical:
Many generic formulations of imidacloprid are available. Read label
carefully for recommended rate. Imidacloprid alone may not control
yellow aphids.

Admire Pro can be applied through a drip irrigation system, as an emitter
spot application, or as a shanked-in emitter adjacent application. See
label for complete details. Apply Admire only to orchards where drip
irrigation has been established for at least 5 years. Use the 14 oz rate for black pecan aphid control.
fungicide: None
biological:
Gibberellic acid is a plant growth regulator that prevents damage from black pecan aphid
feeding and inhibits establishment in the orchard. It does not affect aphids directly and will
not control any other pest, including yellow aphids. Three applications should be made at
2-week intervals, beginning in mid-July, applying 10 oz each time.
Recommendation: ProGibb 4% 10 fl oz/ac

Avoid using broad spectrum insecticides (pyrethroids and chlorpyrifos) earlier in the season to conserve populations of natural enemies (predators and parasitic wasps) which would help in delaying the black pecan aphid outbreaks.

name: Yellow pecan aphids: Monelliopsis pecanis Bissell
symptoms: None
chemical:
Many generic formulations of imidacloprid are available. Read label
carefully for recommended rate. Imidacloprid alone may not control
yellow aphids.

Admire Pro can be applied through a drip irrigation system, as an emitter
spot application, or as a shanked-in emitter adjacent application. See
label for complete details. Apply Admire only to orchards where drip
irrigation has been established for at least 5 years.
fungicide: Resistance with neonicotinyls have been observed with yellow aphids. Rotate among classes of insecticides between treatments to avoid resistance development.
biological: Numerous beneficial arthropods feed on pecan aphids. These include two parasitic wasps, Aphelinus perpallidus Gahan and Trioxys monelliopsis Stary and Marsh. The major predators include lady beetles, Olla abdomminalis (Say), Hippodamia convergens (Guerin-Meneville) and Harmonia axyridis (Pallas); and the lacewings, Chrysopa rufilabris (Burm), Micromus posticus (Walk.) and Hemerobius humulinus (L.)  Other important predators include Zelus exsanguis (Stil), Sinea spinipes (H. And S.), Allochrysa virginica (Fitch), Chrysopa carnea Stephens, Podisus maculiventris (Say), and Allograpta obliqua (Say).  Many spiders also feed heavily on aphids. Two diseases, Entomophthora sp. and Cladosporium sp. infect and kill many blackmargined aphids.

name:
Black rot;
Guignardia bidwellii
symptoms:
The fungus can overwinter on the ground within lesions of infected shoots or as fruit mummies. Ascospores are released and blown by wind and conidia can be produced and spread by splashing rain.
These spores primarily infect and cause disease on both leaves and immature fruit. On leaves, the disease appears as brown spots peppered with black spore structures called pycnidia. On fruit, infected berries may first appear brownish with pycnidia developing on the surface. Eventually the fruit shrivel and become raisin-like mummies riddled with pycnidia and may later fall off of the bunch.
chemical: Effective fungicides applied with proper timing is critical to managing this disease. An early-season application targeting the overwintered inoculum can prevent the initial infection of leaves. The period just before bloom to two weeks after bloom is the most important for protection of fruit.
biological: Sanitation is the primary cultural method of black rot control that aims to minimize the amount of Guignardia bidwellii inoculum in the field. Fruit mummies in the canopy are the primary source of inoculum. All fruit mummies in the canopy should be preferably removed from the field, but can also be dropped to the vineyard floor. During the dormant season, infected canes should be removed by pruning.

name:
Western Flower Thrips: Frankliniella occidentalis
Eastern Flower Thrips:Frankliniella tritici
Soybean thrips: Neohydatothrips variabilis
symptoms:
Symptoms and Signs: 
Peach damage due to thrips in the Southeast is rare, whether on the flowers, leaves or fruit. When it does occur, there are two main types of damage inflicted upon peaches: (1) During bloom; and, (2) Just before and during harvest. 
 
During bloom, the adults and larvae feed on flower parts, as well as developing fruitlets beneath the shuck. This early feeding on fruits causes scarring, which expands as the fruit grows and swells. This damage is known as russeting (shallow brown scars).
 
Right around harvest, adults move from other host plants (usually herbaceous weeds) to the ripening peach fruit. They feed on the surface of the fruit from protected places (like in the stem end, the suture, under leaves and branches touching the fruit, or between adjacent fruits). This feeding empties cell contents, and causes silvering. Silvering is a light to colorless stippling on the surface of the fruit. 
 
Thrips can also be vectors of numerous diseases.

Insect Life Cycle:
Thrips, are generally minor pests of peaches in the Southeast. Adult thrips are slender, tiny insects (less than 1/12than inch), that can be yellow, brown, or black in color. Thrips have two pairs of wings, made mostly of fringe hairs and they have rasping mouthparts that are used to pierce into plant tissues and ingest sap. Larval thrips look like smaller, wingless adults that tend to be lighter in color than adults (ranging from white to a light pinkish). Only the two larval instars after hatching feed before becoming adults – the prepupae and pupal stages do not feed and are generally inactive.
 
Thrips are present and active year-round in the Southeast. They begin to increase in abundance prior to bloom, becoming especially numerous at bloom when pollen availability in high. Reproduction is greatly enhanced when pollen is added to their diets. Females lay from 10 to over 100 eggs into plant tissue, which hatch within 3 to 5 days (sometimes double this when there are cold conditions). Thrips undergo four stages in their development before becoming adults. The first two stages, known as the two larval instars, are the only feeding stages during development. This feeding stage lasts between 4 to 12 days. The prepupae and pupal stages occur in the soil, and last from 3 to 12 days. These last two stages are non-feeding, and immobile stages. The cycle from egg to adult is roughly 3 weeks, with the adults living about a month. There can be up to 5 generations a year, with numerous different generations active in orchards at any given time (especially before and during harvest).​
chemical:
Targeted applications for thrips are rarely needed in peaches. However, if thrips pressure becomes apparent in the spring, carbamates (formetanate; Carzol) before pink, or one of less toxic spinosyns (spinosad; Entrust or SpinTor) during pink at night, can be applied. 

Prior to harvest, if adult and larval feeding is noted on maturing fruit, applications of another spinosyn (spinetoram; Delegate) is effective. Delegate is a longer residual spinosyn, so the potential for thrips to acquire resistance is heightened. Use only if needed.

Insecticide Resistance:
Thrips quickly and readily develop resistances to insecticides. If pressure from thrips become severe enough to warrant insecticide applications, it is important to rotate the insecticide classes (utilizing different Modes of Action, MOA #s) used.
biological: Thrips can be controlled to a large degree in the Southeast through the suppression of weedy growth both in and adjacent to orchards. This will keep thrips abundance in check, thus reducing the migration of adults into the orchard. Also, avoid using pesticides for other target pests which have the propensity to kill beneficials, while leaving thrips generally unaffected. This can cause pesticide-induced population explosions, not only in thrips but other abundant plant feeding pests as well.

name: Alternaria Fruit Rot; Alternaria alternata
symptoms:
Symptoms and Signs
Alternaria rot is characterized by circular, dry, firm, shallow lesions covered with dark, olive green to black surface mycleial growth. The infected tissue is brown, like that caused by brown rot. The disease typically develops near insect feeding injuries, when fruit is overripe, in split pits of fruit, around skin breaks, or at the calyx or stem insertion.

Disease Cycle
The causal organism is saprophytic or weakly pathogenic on many plants. In spore trap studies, the concentration of Alternaria spores in the air increases during and after rain or foggy conditions.  On sweet cherries, the fungus attacks the dead or dying tissue of aborted fruit in the orchard and proceeds into the attached healthy fruit as they mature. Alternaria decay is common even under storage temperatures near 0oC and can cause extensive decay of stone fruit stored for periods of two to three weeks.
chemical:
Chemical Control
The strobilurin class of fungicides (FRAC Group Code 11) are most effective for managing Alternaria rot. Captan and EBDCs are ineffective.
fungicide:
Resistant varieties
Host resistance is not a major component of disease management.
biological:
Cultural Control
Preventing skin injury is key to managing this disease.

name: Brown marmorated stink bug (BMSB) Halyomorpha halys (Stål)
symptoms: BMSB overwinters as an adult in homes, sheds, barns and other fabricated structures.  In warmer climates it may also overwinter in wooded areas, often adjacent to orchards and other agroecosystems.  BMSB feeds on wild hosts early season.  Agricultural commodities become vulnerable as soon as fruits begin to form.  Feeding often increases as it prepares to move back to over-wintering sites, building up its carbohydrate stores for overwintering.
chemical:
