<![endif]--><!--StartFragment-->Insecticides in the carbamate, neonicotinoid and pyrethroid chemical classes can effectively control the brown marmorated stinkbug.  However, continuous migration of adults and newly emerged nymphs from surrounding vegetation requires frequent reapplication. Pyrethroids and carbamates are highly toxic to beneficial insect predators and repeated use of these materials can lead to the severe outbreaks of secondary pests such as mites, aphids and scales due to reduced native predators.<!--EndFragment-->
fungicide: None known at this time, however, due to the destructive nature of this pest, resistance management is paramount to continued variety of chemical traetment methods.  Rotation of IRAC codes is critical.
biological: Trissolcus japonicus (Ashmead), AKA the samurai wasp, is a parasitiod from the native range of BMSB.  In lab studies the Samurai wasp has been shown to preferentially prey on the egg masses of this invasive insect.  While conducting a study of egg parasitism by native predators, T. japonicus was discovered in sentinel BMSB egg masses in Beltsville MD in 2014.  T. japonicus has since been positively identified in other locations on both the east and west coasts.  As yet, the samurai wasp is not permitted to be released intentionally for use in any BMSB managment program or for any other reason.

name: Brown marmorated stink bug: Halyomorpha halys (Stal)
symptoms:
Life cycle:
The brown marmorated stink bug overwinters inside houses and other dwellings and emerge in early spring, immediately moving to feed on available host plants. BMSB adults and nymphs are known to feed on over 100 different host plants, with peaches being one of their ‘favorite’ plants. BMSB ability to survive and reproduce on various plants and unrestricted movement among various hosts is one of the main factors contributing to the continuous and quite unpredictable presence of this pest in orchards. Feeding damage on fruit caused by BMSB can occur throughout most of the season. Both, immature and adult BMSB can cause the injury to the fruit. 

Monitoring: 
Visual observations and monitoring traps baited with BMSB aggregation pheromone are the most effective tools to monitor the occurrence of BMSB adults and nymphs. Commercial traps and lures for BMSB monitoring are available for purchase and should be placed adjacent to orchards at the beginning of the season. Although traps by themselves will not control BMSB, by capturing adults and nymphs, traps can be utilized as an early warning system. With a constant threat of new BMSB adults migrating into the orchard from surrounding vegetation such as woods or field crops, monitoring traps are the most practical tools to detect the presence of this pest.
 
Symptoms and Signs: 
The feeding on leaf buds, flower buds, and blooms can cause the buds to wither and abort, failing to bloom. After petal fall, when tarnished plant bugsand stink bugnumbers can precipitously increase, the feeding is mainly on young fruit. When feeding, the cells in the tissue surrounding the wound are destroyed. This causes scarring, which leads to ‘cat-facing’ injury as the fruit continues to grow and swell. Significant cat-facing damage can make the peach unmarketable. After pit hardening, most stink bug feeding doesn’t cause much scarring or distortion – but the fruit around feeding sites can become dry, corky, and/or slightly sunken areas in the peach.
chemical: Insecticides with various modes of action can effectively control the brown marmorated stink bug. While a number of commonly used products are effective against this pest (e.g., neonicotinoids, carbamates, or pyrethroids), the continuous challenge revolves around the unrestricted influx of new stink bug adults from surrounding vegetation and therefore causes the necessity of multiple, repeated applications of insecticides. Pyrethroids and carbamates are very toxic to beneficial insects and frequent use of these products can lead to the severe outbreaks of secondary pests such as mites and scales.
fungicide: As of spring 2017, no documented instances of insecticide resistance are known to exist among BMSB populations, however differences in BMSB sensitivity to various compounds within the same IRAC group such as pyrethroids (IRAC Group 3A) or neonicotinoids (IRAC Group 4A) are frequently observed. Please see the list of recommended products under “Active ingredients” in this application.
biological: The native biological control agents are not effective in controlling BMSB. Although some biological control provided by generalist predators, parasitoids or birds is possible, in commercial agricultural setting such control is frequently not sufficient and targeted applications of insecticides are necessary. No other alternative methods to manage BMSB are currently available.

name: hi
symptoms: hi
chemical: hi
fungicide: hi
biological: hi

name: Plum curculio, Conotrachelus nenuphar (Herbst)
symptoms:
The plum curculio passes through four stages of development: egg, larva, pupa and adult. The life cycle starts when an overwintered adult female lays individual eggs under the skin of the developing apple fruit, first using her mouthparts to cut a small crescent shaped flap in the fruit skin and then turning around to deposit an egg. Within 4-11 days of being laid, larvae hatch from the eggs and tunnel into the flesh of the fruit as they feed. Larvae complete four instars inside the fruit in about 16 days. Pupation occurs in the soil and lasts between 4-5 weeks.

In the early spring, most plum curculio activity takes place during the first warm period after petal fall, when the maximum temperature is 70°F or higher for 2-3 consecutive days. Periods of cool, rainy weather with maximum temperatures below 60°F are not suitable for adult activity. In Massachusetts, the onset of plum curculio immigration has been observed, using odor-baited traps, to occur when approximately 225 DD (base 43°F) have accumulated since January 1st.  Because colonization of host trees by adult plum curculios in the spring may occur before, during, or after blossoming, feeding may occur first on the buds, flowers and, subsequently, newly set fruit.  In the Northeast, plum curculios complete only one generation per year. Upon emergence from pupae during the summer, adults feed on fruit but do not mate. Subsequently, summer-generation adults overwinter, and then re-appear in host trees the following spring. Adult plum curculios primarily overwinter in forest leaf litter. In spring, as soon as adult plum curculios emerge from overwintering quarters they feed on buds, blossoms and subsequently on newly set fruit.
chemical:
Petal fall is the critical period for protection. To protect bees, always wait until bloom is completely over to apply any insecticide. The majority of eggs deposited into fruit by overwintered plum curculios in the Northeast is completed in apples once 308 DD base 50 following petal fall has been reached on McIntosh apples. Therefore, a spray residue should be maintained until 308 DD base 50 have been reached.

In recent years, a monitoring system for plum curculio termed ‘trap trees’ was developed in Massachusetts. The trap-tree approach operates by aggregating adult plum curculios and subsequently egg-laying injury in the canopies of select perimeter-row apple trees that are baited with the synergistic two-component lure comprised of the fruit volatile benzaldehyde and grandisoic acid, the plum curculio aggregation pheromone. Baiting selected perimeter row trees with these olfactory attractants results in an approximately 20-fold increase in aggregation of oviposition injury in these particular canopies. Trap trees are baited just before petal fall. After a full block petal fall insecticide application is applied, these trap trees are monitored for signs of fresh oviposition injury.  If a threshold of one freshly injured fruit out of 25 sampled is found on a perimeter row trap tree, a subsequent insecticide application to the peripheral rows is recommended. Using this threshold, not only were economically acceptable low levels (0.77% on average) of orchard-wide injury to fruit by plum curculio recorded at harvest in Massachusetts commercial orchard blocks, but also important reductions in insecticide use were achieved when compared with the conventional approach involving three whole-block sprays. Because trap trees are also sprayed with insecticide, they also serve as excellent indicators of the extent to which insecticide residue remains effective against plum curculio, thereby complementing the use of cumulative heat unit models.
fungicide: While not currently an issue rotation of chemical classes should be used in order to reduce risk of resistance developing.
biological:
Keeping the orchard floor closely mowed after harvest provides areas that are less suitable for within-orchard overwintering.

Removing and destroying fallen fruit in late June and July will break the plum curculio lifecycle, reducing the number of adults that otherwise would be present in the orchard during the summer (causing feeding injury to apple fruit) and would overwinter.

name: Flea Beetle
symptoms:
Symptoms and Signs
Flea beetle feeding produces shot-hole damage on blueberry foliage and is often clustered on terminals.

Life Cycle
Flea beetles overwinter as eggs in the litter near the base of blueberry canes. Once plants start to develope in the spring, typically around mid-May, the eggs will hatch and the larvae will feed on the flush of new growth. The larvae will drop to the ground and form pupa in late June. After about two weeks the adutls will emerge and begin feeding on the plant foliage through late summer and then lay eggs around July to August.
chemical:
Insecticides
Insecticides recommended for spotted wing drosophila (SWD) control are also effective against flea beetle, so additional applications for flea beetle management are not necessary if these products are in use. Effective products include:  Assail 30SG, Asana XL 0.66EC, Admire Pro 4.6F, Entrust SC, Entrust 80W.
fungicide: None
biological:
Cultural Control
Since flea beetles overwinter as eggs in leaf littler beneath the plants a fall or spring burn can help control pest populations.

name: Gypsy moth Lymantria dispar
biological: While not practical on a large scale, scrapping egg masses off surfaces and destrying them can be helpful.  Tape, wrapped around trunks, sticky side out, will trap caterpillars climbing toward the canopies where they feed on foliage.

name: Grape root borer, Vitacea polistiformis(Harris)
symptoms:
Adult moths emerge from the soil early to mid-summer. Within eight days of emergence, females lay eggs on the soil surface, grape leaves, and weeds near base of vine. The eggs hatch on the soil surface and the larvae tunnels into the root system. The larvae then spend 22 months feeding in the roots. During the summer of the second year, the larvae pupate near the soil surface before emerging as adults, repeating the cycle.
 
Symptoms and Signs:
Damage caused by larval feeding can range from just a few feeding sites to complete root system destruction. Borer damage causes reduced vine growth, smaller leaves and reduced berry size. Because damage is restricted to below ground, problems often go unnoticed until the vines start to die. 
 
Monitoring:
Injury by GRB is often most severe in low, poorly drained areas of the vineyard. Grape root borer presence can be determined by regular root inspection or the detection of shed pupal skins at the base of the vines. In mid-summer, growers should examine around the bases of vines out to a distance of 18 inches for empty pupal skins of grape root borer.
 
Pheromone-baited traps are available and can be used to monitor adult activity. Traps should be placed in the vineyard mid-June. While the number of moths collected in the traps do not necessarily correlate with root infestations, moth detections can be used to determine insecticide application timing.
chemical: Control of this pest can be difficult as there is currently only a single insecticide registered, Lorsban 4E, which has a 35 day preharvest interval. Using pheromone-baited traps as a monitoring tool, once moths are caught early to mid-summer, initiate the application of insecticide to the base of the vines. Do not allow this spray to contact the fruit or foliage.
fungicide: Resistance has not been documented at this time.
biological: A mating disruption product, Isomate GRB, is registered for use in grapes, and at a rate of 100 ties per acre can be highly effective. Additionally, proper weed management below the vines is also important for reducing potential egg laying sites and to increase mortality due to larval and egg desiccation.

name:
Alternaria fruit rot;
Alternaria spp.
symptoms: The fungus produces brown to gray to black mycelium on fruit surfaces and readily produces spores which are disseminated by wind and rain. The fungus has a broad host range and can overwinter in infested plant debris. Conidial spores that land on damaged fruit can invade and eventually colonize an entire bunch.
chemical: Although a small selection of fungicides are labeled for this disease, fungicide applications are typically not necessary since it has been a minor concern. Fungicides applied for other fruit rot diseases are typically effective against this pathogen as well.
fungicide: Resistance or insensitivity to QoI (FRAC 11), SDHI (FRAC 7), and MBC (FRAC1) fungicides has been reported in Alternaria species in other cropping systems.
biological: Keep fruit healthy and intact to prevent this disease by preventing damage from insects, birds, and other pathogens.

name:
Anthracnose;
Elsinoe ampelina
symptoms: Lesions on leaves and shoots can be sunken with gray centers, surrounded by a reddish brown to purple-black margin. These lesions can be confused for hail damage, however unlike hail damage, this disease will occur on all sides of shoots. The appearance of fruit lesions is what gives this disease its other name, birds eye rot. Lesions have reddish brown to black margins and fungal fruiting structures may develop in the brown center, yielding pinkish spores. Fruit are susceptible to infection from before flowering until veraison.
chemical: If this disease has been an issue in the past, fungicides can be an effective management option. An application of liquid lime sulfur in early spring followed by foliar applications during the rest of the season are most effective. Some fungicides are labeled and effective against anthracnose as well as other foliar diseases.
fungicide: N/A
biological: As this fungus can overwinter on shoots, pruning and removing (from the vineyard) infected shoots during the dormant season is effective. Remove alternative hosts that can be an inoculum source such as wild grapes growing close to the vineyard. Leaf removal or pruning practices that allow airflow through the canopy will create a less favorable environment for the pathogen.

name:
Bitter rot;
Greeneria uvicola
symptoms: The first symptoms of bitter rot are more easily visible on white-wine cultivars and appear as brownish, water soaked spots on post-veraison berries. As the disease progresses, concentric rings of fungal fruiting bodies called acervuli appear on the fruit surface. Unlike black rot diseases fruit, handling fruit with bitter rot may leave hands with a sooty appearance.
chemical: Proper identification of this disease is critical to chemical control. Bitter rot reduces yield like black rot and ripe rot, but small amounts of bitter rot-symptomatic fruit processed for wine will result in very poor wine quality. Infection and disease from bitter rot occurs as sugars increase in the fruit, therefore fungicides applied at this timing are crucial for bitter rot prevention.
biological: Canopy management or weed control methods that improve air circulation will make a less favorable environment for the pathogen. Removal of mummified fruit from the vineyard will decrease inoculum for the following season.

name:
Botrytis bunch rot;
Botrytis cinerea
symptoms: Botrytis cinerea can infect all succulent tissues of the plant with adequate wetness and temperature. Flowers and wounded tissue are considered to be the most susceptible, the pathogen may remain dormant in infected flowers until after varaison. At this time the disease can take over an entire cluster both pre- and post-harvest. In the dormant season, the fungus can overwinter in mummified fruit, other plant parts or on alternative hosts.
chemical: Effective fungicides applied at the appropriate times provide significant control. The flowering stage is considered to be the most critical time for Botrytis bunch rot prevention. Basal leaf pulling may result in greater spray coverage.
fungicide: Botrytis cinerea is notorious for fungicide resistance, with widespread resistance to methyl benzimidazole carbamates (FRAC code 1) and strobilurins (FRAC code 11). High levels of resistance to cyprodinil (FRAC 9), fenhexamid (FRAC 17), and iprodione (FRAC 2) were also found in Mid-Atlantic vineyards. Prevent resistance by only spraying when necessary, and by using multi-site fungicides such ascaptan.
biological: Manage canopy to facilitate drying of plant surfaces. Prevent damage to the fruit that could be caused by leaf pulling, insects and birds. Removing mummified fruit and managing the ground cover can reduce inoculum for following seasons.

name:
Phomopsis cane and leaf spot;
Phomopsis viticola
symptoms: This disease mostly appears as spots on canes and leaves, however the pathogen can also infect rachises, flowers, and fruit. Spots on canes start as small black spots, but can grow along the cane and may eventually crack, exposing the brown cane under the lesion. Spots on leaves also start small and black, but heavy disease can lead to the deformation and death of the entire leaf. Fruit rot occurs after veraison and first appears light-brown, advancing to shriveling, and dots (pycnidia). These symptoms resemble black rot, except that phomopsis occurs later in the season.
chemical: Early-season applications can protect leaves and canes, and the choice of effective fungicides is important for chemical control. A treatment of liquid lime sulfur at budbreak can reduce the viability of overwintered pathogens like phomopsis. Foliar treatments during the growing season are also effective.
biological: Use pruning methods that encourage airflow in the canopy, and prune and destroy infected canes.

name:
Ripe rot;
Colletotrichum spp.
symptoms: Spores (conidia) of Colletotrichum spp. can infect pedicels and fruit at all stages, and plant parts infected early in the season can produce a second round of spores able to infect fruit close to harvest. Although infection can occur throughout the growing season, symptoms do not develop until after veraison. Symptoms are more likely to occur when weather is warm and wet. Infected fruit left in the field can overwinter and repeat this disease cycle the following season.
chemical: Early season chemical control aimed at Botrytis bunch rot or black rot can also be effective against ripe rot. If conditions are favorable for ripe rot near harvest, make an application of an effective fungicide with a short post-harvest interval.
fungicide: In other crops, Colletotrichum spp. have been found to be resistant to some fungicides, most commonly strobilurins (FRAC code 11). Prevent resistance by only spraying when necessary, use fungicides with low resistance risk, and alternate modes of action between sprays.
biological: Canopy management or weed control methods that improve air circulation will make a less favorable environment for the pathogen. Removal of mummified fruit from the vineyard will decrease inoculum for the following season.

name:
Sour rot;
Acetobacter
symptoms: Sour rot only occurs close to harvest, after veraison. Both wounding of fruit, yeast, and fruit flies which transmit acetic acid bacteria are considered to be key to this disease. In one study, the bacteria and yeasts associated with sour rot were not able to cause this disease on their own. Sour rot only occured when fruit flies were introduced.
chemical: Fungicides and bactericides are not effective against sour rot. Insecticide sprays targeted at fruit flies have been effective options.
biological: Prevent fruit wounding. Wounded fruit are a key component to the development of sour rot, yet fruit wounding can occur in many ways. Insects, birds, leaf-pulling, powdery mildew, rapid growth, and tight clusters can all be entry points for this disease.

name: Two-spotted Spider Mite: Tetranychus urticae Koch
symptoms:
Symptoms and Signs: 
The likelihood of the greatest mite pressure, possibly inflicting the most damage, is from June through August – when mite abundance can rapidly increase. These tiny arachnids (the same group as spiders, scorpions, ticks, harvestmen, etc.; closely related to insects and crustaceans) insert their minute piercing mouthparts into individual cells of plants, primarily leaves (occasionally fruit), and extract the contents. This includes the chlorophyll, the green pigment in plants, which leads to loss of color (bronzing) in the leaves of heavily infested plants. These leaves will typically be lost. 

Peaches, in general, are much more tolerant than other orchard fruits to mite pressures. They can withstand mild to even relatively high mite infestations, though loss in fruit size and quality can arise if heavy infestations begin early in the season and persist thereafter. If heavy mite pressure continues for a long period without control, and moderate to substantial defoliation occurs, this can tree can potentially experience much reduced vigor, a markedly lower fruit yield, and a overall decline in health the following year.

Life Cycle:
The two-spotted mite overwinters as an adult female in ground debris or soil, and become active early spring. This female lays eggs (fertilized eggs become females, unfertilized eggs become males) on herbaceous vegetation, which become mature adults within 5-10 days. There are multiple generations per year.
chemical:
The primary means of control are covered during the two (2) applications of horticultural oils during the dormant/delayed-dormant period for targeting scale. If needed, targeted Summer applications of miticides can be used as needed. The preferred choices are curative miticides (e.g. Acramite, Nexter, or Envidor) used in rotation. Envidor has more efficacy in killing eggs and nymphs than adults. BE SURE TO ALTERNATE MITICIDES, as mites readily develop resistance to miticides.

Avoid over-application of pyrethroid in the summer/fall, as these sprays have a tremendous impact on predatory mites, while minimal long-term impact on two-spotted or European red mite populations.
fungicide: Mites quickly and readily develop resistance to miticides. Be sure to rotate the miticides used during outbreaks, and only targeted sprays where mite pressures are high enough to warrant application.
biological:
Beneficials, such as predatory mites, are a major component in the control of pest mite pressures. 
Avoid over-application of pyrethroid in the summer/fall, as these sprays have a tremendous impact on predatory mites, while minimal long-term impact on two-spotted or European red mite populations.
Also, control of broadleaf weeds in the orchard helps diminish the pressure from two-spotted mites, which prefer the herbaceous vegetation, moving into the trees when/if populations grow to large numbers.

name:
Hoverfly
(Diptera: Syrphidae)
symptoms:
Introduction
Flies in the family Syrphidae are commonly known as syrphid flies, hoverflies, or flower flies. Syrphidae is one of the most diverse families of Diptera with nearly 6000 described species. Within the family of Syphidae the subfamily Syrphinae consists of primarily aphidophagous (consumes aphids) species of syrphids. Numerous adult hoverflies are considered mimics of stinging wasps and bees, and are frequently abundant on flowers, which are used as mating sites and food sources. Hoverfly larvae feed on aphids, scale insects, and thrips, and are considered extremely beneficial since each larva is capable of consuming hundreds of aphids during its development. 
 
Appearance
Hoverflies generally have small, chalky white eggs that resemble a small grain of rice.  Adult females lay eggs singly on leaves, usually in or near an aphid colony. The larvae are 4 to 5 mm long, translucent, green to cream colored, and have a visible digestive system. The larvae also have no eyes and are typically maggot-shaped; tapering to a point at the head end and broadly rounded at the rear.  The mouthparts consist of a triple-pointed stylet that is used to seize and pierce prey in order to suck them dry.  
 
Adult hoverflies are fast and agile flyers, often seen hovering over flowers (hence their common name). They are 5 to 9 mm in length and superficially resemble bees or wasps, but have a more flattened body and only one pair of clear wings. Although the tip of the abdomen is pointed in some species of hoverflies, they do not have a stinger or a chewing mouthparts, unlike bees and wasps, so they are harmless to humans. They also have large, often reddish eyes with a v-shaped notch on the back margin of each eye. 
 
Life Cycle
Hoverflies overwinter as late-instar larvae or pupae in the soil or in leaf litter. Adults begin emerging in early Spring and require nectar and pollen from flowering plants in order to build up enough energy to begin mating and producing eggs. After mating, female syrphids oviposit eggs on leaves near or in host (e.g. aphids) colonies, where the young larvae will hatch and easily locate their prey. The larvae feed and grow for 7 to 10 days, and then drop to the soil or leaf litter to pupate.  The hoverfly life cycle is completed in 16 to 28 days and the adults can live up to a month, allowing for multiple generations each year.  The final generation of larvae will overwinter as either late-instars or pupae, emerging the following spring to repeat the cycle.
 
Pests Attacked
Adult hoverflies are not predaceous and mainly feed on nectar and pollen. The larvae, on the other hand, are voracious predators of aphids, scales, thrips, and even small caterpillars. 
 
Relative Effectiveness
Worldwide, predaceous hoverfly larvae are an important naturally occurring control agent of aphids and other soft-bodied pest insects in agricultural systems, and in a few cases have even been documented as the principal aphid predator. The ability hoverfly larvae to effectively suppress aphids depends on variety of factors, such as climate, time of emergence, habitat quality and the presence of flowers for pollen and nectar.  Efforts to manipulate agricultural landscapes to provide shelter with hedgerows and food from flowering plants have been able to increase the supportive nature of agricultural systems for syrphids as well as other beneficial insects.
chemical:
Pesticide Susceptibility
Hoverflies are highly susceptible to broad-spectrum insecticides, especially within the first 24 hours of insecticide application. It is recommended to avoid broad-spectrum insecticidal control of aphid infestations if you see syrphid flies within or adjacent to fields.

name: Peach Rust; Tranzschelia discolor
symptoms:
Symptoms & Signs
Peach rust can occur on shoots, leaves and fruit, while leaf lesions are the most common symptom. Especially young stems can get infected in early spring by Tanzschelia discolor and develop twig cankers. These appear as splits and water-soaked lesions on the upper side of the twig. Within a few days, they produce powdery rusty-brown masses of spores that now can cause an infection on the leaves nearby through the summer. Leaf lesions first appear on both surfaces of the leaf as pale, then as green-yellowish spots. On the upper surface, they turn angular and bright yellow and develop necrotic halos while on the lower surface they become rusty-brown pustules producing spore masses. These spores again can infect nearby leaves or fruit. An early infection in the season, therefore, leads to premature defoliation and fruit infection at harvest. Because fruit lesions turn up during the season normally after leaf infection it is not a big issue on early maturing varieties. On the contrary, later-maturing varieties develop lesions as brownish small spots with a green halo on immature fruit. Through maturing of the fruit the halos become greenish-yellow and sink in the fruit several millimeters. However, not all symptoms necessarily occur each growing season and not necessarily in this exact order.

Disease Cycle
The disease cycle of peach rust includes four different stages of spores built in sexual or asexual reproduction on two different hosts. Infections occurring on twigs and leaves of peach trees are first caused by the aeciospores of Tanzschelia discolor. That represents the start of the asexual cycle. The developing rust pustules contain thousands of urediniospores each. By eruption of these pustules, the urediniospores infect nearby leaves or fruit again, meaning they are able to re-infect as a secondary inoculum. This makes urediniospores the most important inoculum causing peach rust. The spores are hereby spread by wind and rain, which is why high rainfalls and long wetness periods in spring lead to high levels of infection during the growing season. Germination is found to happen in a broad range of temperature, from 5 to 30°C with an optimal temperature from 15 to 20°C. However, urediniospores are short-lived. They can overwinter in leaf pustules or twig cankers being the primary inoculum in the next season but they cannot survive host dormancy. Therefore, the sexual cycle begins including an alternate host. In late season teliospores are produced as overwintering structures and germinate to basidiospores in the next growing season. Basidiospores then infect the alternate host Anemone coronaria, the poppy anemone, Spanish marigold, or windflower, on which aeciospores are produced and again can infect peach trees. Now the whole disease cycle starts all over again. However, the alternate host Anemone coronaria plays only a minor role in infecting peach. The main inoculum source for spring is considered to be urediniospores.
chemical: Many peach cultivars seem susceptible to the disease, however, there are differences in tolerance. During an outbreak of the disease in South Carolina in 2019, ‘PF23’ was highly susceptible; ‘Carotiger’ and ‘Julyprince’ were susceptible; and Guardian rootstock trees were resistant. Chemical control should start after the trees leafed out and before the first symptoms of rust appear. Sterol Biosynthesis Inhibitor fungicides (FRAC 3), succinate-dehydrogenase-inhibitor fungicides (FRAC 7) and quinone-outside-inhibitor fungicides (FRAC 11) are most effective, however, captan will also manage the disease.
fungicide: None available
biological: Pruning out twig cankers will reduce disease and scouting the orchard for disease will help with IPM implementation. Because humidity and wetness benefit the infection of peach trees through spreading the spores, management of sprinkler directions and irrigation schedules is very important too.

name: Glomerella Leaf Spot and Fruit Rot, Colletotrichum gloeosporiodes species complex
symptoms:
Leaf Symptoms: In the Southeastern United States, initial symptoms of GLS are usually observed by late May in unmanaged orchards. Young lesions of Glomerella leaf spot on the foliage appear as small purple flecks, but rapidly expand into irregularly shaped necrotic lesions that are tan in color surrounded by a purple border. Often concentric lesions can be observed within the developing lesions. Acervuli or perithecia may form on lesions under ideal climate conditions. Infected leaves eventually become chlorotic and defoliate prematurely. It is not uncommon to observe 75% defoliation in non-sprayed orchards by mid-July.

Fruit Symptoms: Fruit may become infected with fungi from the Colletotrichum gloeosporioides complex as early as bloom, but due to pathogen activity and weather conditions, primary infections are usually initiated around petal fall or later. Although to fruit may occur during this time, symptoms and signs of the pathogen may not appear until fruit matures in late summer. Similar to bitter rot caused by fungi in the Colltotrichum acutatum species complex, bitter rot caused by Colletotrichum gloeosporioides fungi begins as a a small light brown/tan circular lesion that becomes sunken and darker as the disease advances. On yellow-skinned cultivars, a red halo may be present around the spots. Fruit spots may develop into rots as fruit matures or during the postharvest period. The development of acervuli and presence of conidia are less common on fruit infected by species in the C. gloeosporioides complex compared to infections by the C. acutatum species complex.

Disease Cycle: Colletotrichum fungi causing Glomerella leaf spot and the associated bitter rot overwinter on infected fallen leaves, mummified fruit, cankers caused by wood rotting pathogens or the fire blight pathogen Erwinia amylovora, and buds. Ascopores and conidia are released and dispersed primarily during rain events starting in the spring.  Both conidia and ascospores germinate in free water and tissue can be infected at any age. Unlike many fruit rot pathogens, fungi in the C. gloeosporioides complex can penetrate fruit directly without the presence of a wound. Optimal conditions for disease development include high relative humidity (>95%), and warm temperatures (59-85 deg. F).
chemical: Fungicide applications beginning at early petal fall and continuing through harvest are important for the control of Glomerella leaf spot and bitter rot. Captan and mancozeb, QoI fungicides such as Sovran or Flint Extra, or SDHI/QoI premixed products such as Pristine WG, Merivon, and Luna Sensation, are effective against the C. gloeosporioides complex. Fungicides should be applied on a 7 to 10 day interval
fungicide: Resistance to QoI fungicides (FRAC 11) in populations of Colletotrichum fructicola and Colletotrichum siamense have been confirmed in the eastern United States.
biological:
Cultural Control: Sanitation is critical for the control of Glomerella leaf spot and bitter rot caused by fungi in the C. gloeosporioides complex. Winter pruning and destruction of shoots infected with the fire blight bacterium and cankers, and fruit mummies is recommended. Removing fruit drops and infected fruit can help to reduce secondary inoculum throughout the season. Applications of urea, flail mowing, and/or leaf removal from the orchard can help reduce inoculum for the upcoming season.

Resistant Varieties: With the exception of 'Granny Smith', Glomerella leaf spot has not been observed on cultivars that do not have 'Golden Delicious' as a parent.

name: Common henbit (Lamium amplexicaule)
symptoms: Common henbit is a winter annual that germinates in late summer or early fall and grows over the winter and then flowers in spring or early summer.  It can produce over 2000 seeds per plant.
chemical:
In the strawberry bed, flumioxazin, sulfentrazone, or oxyfluorfen can be applied preplant to the preformed bed for henbit control.  No postemergence herbicides are registered for application in the bed. The only option after germination for control in the planting holes is hand removal.  In the row middles, flumioxazin can be applied prior to henbit germination as a hooded or shielded spray application.  However, it will reduce germination of ryegrass if applied prior to germination or it will injure/kill emerged ryegrass.  Do not apply flumioxazin after fruit set or crop spotting may occur on the fruit.  Adding an adjuvant may cause spots on the foliage or fruit if spray comes in contact with the strawberry plant. 
Paraquat, carfentrazone, and glyphosate can be applied when henbit is small
fungicide: None
biological: The only option for control of henbit that emerges after strawberry planting in the strawberry planting holes is hand removal.

name: Predatory Stink Bugs
symptoms:
Introduction
Stink bugs are common pests and can be difficult to manage in many cropping systems, but they are not all bad. There are a few species that are actually quite beneficial. For example, spined soldier bugs (Podisusspp.) and the florida predatory stink bug (Euthyrhynchus floridanus) are two groups of predatory stink bugs that feed on a variety of pest bugs, beetles, and caterpillars.
 
 
Appearance
Spined soldier bug (Podisus spp.)
The eggs are barrel-shaped, approximately 1 mm in diameter, with long, spine-like projections around the circumference of the top. The eggs are laid in masses of 17 to 70 at a time. Once hatched, the nymphs mature through five growth stages (instars), starting with the small (1.3-1.5 mm), red and black first instar nymphs, developing in to the larger (8-10 mm) fifth instar nymphs with visible wing pads and are mottled brown with tan, black, or red abdominal markings. The adults are approximately 11-13 mm long, mottled brown in color, with spines on either side of the thorax (“shoulders”). Another unique characteristic of spined soldier bug adults is a distinctive dark line on the membranous tip of each forewing that form one dark streak when the wing tips overlap.
 
Florida predatory stink bug (Euthyrhynchus floridanus)
Similar to other predatory stink bugs, eggs are approximately 1 mm in diameter, somewhat barrel-shaped with short, spine-like projections around the top. Eggs are generally laid in masses of 20 to 90 at a time. Once hatched, the nymphs mature through five growth stages (instars). The first instar nymphs are approximately 1.5 mm long with a blue-black head and thorax and red abdomen with dark central and lateral stripes composed of dorsal and lateral dark-colored plates. All five instars have a similar appearance, except that the fifth instar is 8 to 9 mm long with prominent wing pads, which are blue-black. The adults are approximately 12 to 17 mm and have a reddish-orange spot at each of the three corners of the scutellum (triangle area posterior of the thorax) outlined against an irradescent blue-black body. 
 
 
Life Cycle
Spined soldier bug
Time from egg to adult ranges from 27 to 38 days, with the egg stage lasting five to nine days, with adults living approximately one to four months.
 
Florida predatory stink bug
Time from egg to adult ranges from 58 to 100 days, with the egg stage lasting 18 to 33 days.
 Pests Attacked
Predatory stink bugs are generalist predators with a broad host range, including several important economic pests. They feed as adults and nymphs on a variety of other arthropods, particularly larval forms of Lepidoptera and Coleoptera, and pest stink bugs. Specifically reported prey include the larvae of Mexican bean beetle, European corn borer, diamondback moth, corn earworm, beet armyworm, fall armyworm, cabbage looper, imported cabbageworm, Colorado potato beetle, velvetbean caterpillar, and flea beetles.
 
 
Relative Effectiveness
It has been recorded that an individual spined soldier bug can consume more than 100 fall armyworm larvae in a lifetime.
 
Although not as widely distributed, the Florida predatory stink bugs are also considered beneficial because most of its prey consists of plant-damaging bugs, beetles, and caterpillars.
chemical:
Pesticide Susceptibility
Predatory stink bugs are highly susceptible to broad-spectrum insecticides, particularly organophosphates and carbamates. They are also susceptible to other broad-spectrum insecticides, such as pyrethroids and neonicotinoids.

name: Black cherry aphid Myzus cerasi
symptoms: Overwinter as eggs on bark or buds. Hatches in spring before bud break and infests emerging foliage. Nymphs reproduce asexually and rapidly producing several generations. Winged adults migrate to plants of the mustard family in summer with few aphids remaining on cherry. Adults leave alternate hosts and mate and lay eggs on cherry in the fall.
chemical: A delayed dormant oil application should be the first step, followed by early spring scouting (shortly after bud break) for signs of infestation. If deemed necessary, an effective insecticide should be applied before the populations build and become inaccessibe within curled foliage.
fungicide: NA
biological: Using insecticides in the orchard that are harmful to beneficial insects should be avoided. Tart cherry are not favored by black cherry aphid.

name: Lady Beetle (Coleoptera: Coccinellidae)
symptoms:
Introduction
Lady beetles, also known as lady bird beetles or ladybugs, are among the most visible and best known beneficial predatory insects. Over 450 species are found in North America. Some, like the convergent lady beetle (Hippodamia convergens) are native, whereas others, such as the multicolored Asian lady beetle (Harmonia axyridis) have been introduced from other countries.
 
Common native species include:
Chilocorus stigma (Twice-stabbed lady beetle)
Coleomegilla maculata (Pink spotted lady beetle)
Hippodamia convergens (Convergent lady beetle
Stethorus punctum (Spider mite destroyer)
 
Common introduced species:
Coccinella septempunctata (Seven-spotted lady beetle)
Cryptolaemus montrouzieri (Mealybug destroyer)
Harmonia axyridis (Multicolored Asian lady beetle)
Rodolia cardinalis (Vedalia beetle)
 
Appearance
Eggs lady beetles are usually laid near prey, such as aphids, often in small clusters in protected sites on leaves and stems. The eggs are small (about 1 mm), cream, yellow, or orange in color, and spindle-shaped. The larvae are spiny, 'alligator'-shaped are often dark grey or black with orange or yellow markings. 
 
Adult lady beetles are small, round to oval, and dome-shaped. They can range from 1.5 mm (Stethorus punctum) to 8 mm (Coccinella septempunctata) in size. The stereotypical lady beetle coloration is red elytra (wing case) with black markings, but ladty beetles come in a variety of colors, such as orange, yellow, or even black. Additionally, the area immediately behind the head, the pronotum, may also have a distinctive pattern. For example, the multicolored Asian lady beetle has a distinctive “M” (composed of lines or dots) on its pronotum when the head is pointing upwards (or a “W” when pointing downwards). The color and pattern of markings for each lady beetle species may vary, but these differences can aid in identification. 
 
 
Life Cycle
Lady beetles overwinter as adults, often in aggregations along hedgerows, beneath leaf litter, under rocks, beneath bark, or in other protected places. The multicolored Asian lady beetles are notorious for entering homes and buildings in the Fall to overwinter. In spring, the adults disperse in search of prey and suitable egg laying sites. Female adults may lay from 20 to 1,000 eggs over a one to three month period. The subsequent larvae grow from less than 1 mm to about 1 cm in length, typically through four larval instars, over a 20 to 30 day period. Adults may live for a few months to over a year. 
 
 
Pests Attacked
Lady beetles are very helpful predators for producers of a variety of crops, such as tree fruits, small fruits, nuts, vegetables, grain crops, and legumes. Basically, any  crop that is attacked by aphids, mites, or mealybugs will benefit from these predaceous beetles.
 
 
Relative Effectiveness
Lady beetles are voracious feeders as adults and larvae. For example, the convergent lady beetle may eat its weight in aphids every day as a larva and consume as many as 50 aphids per day as an adult. Once a food source, such as an aphid colony, is diminished, the beetles will disperse in search for additional food.
 
 
Pesticide Susceptibility
Pesticide susceptibility may be influenced by prior exposure of the lady beetle population to the chemical and/or the species, and as such there is considerable variation in their susceptibility to pesticides. Generally, though, broad-spectrum insecticides, such as organophosphates and carbamates, are highly toxic to lady beetles.

name: Common chickweed (Stellaria media)
symptoms: A winter annual that germinates in the fall grows during the winter and produces small white flowers and seeds in the spring.
chemical:
In the strawberry row:  A preplant application of flumioxazin, sulfentrazone or oxyfluorfen applied to the preformed bed prior to laying plastic should control this weed.  No postemergence herbicide options are available in the row.  

In the strawberry row middle:
fungicide: None
biological: If chickweed emerges in the crop holes after strawberry is planted the only option is hand removal.

name: Common vetch
symptoms: A winter annual weed that germinates in the fall or winter and grow during any warm weather which may occur in the winter.  It produces flowers and seed in the spring and dies as temperatures increase in the late spring and early summer.
chemical: No preemergence herbicides are registered in strawberry that will control vetch.  Apply Stinger as a postemergence banded application over the strawberry row or to the row middles between plastic rows or as a spot treatment.  Do not apply as a broadcast treatment over the strawberry row and row middles.   Generally only 0.3 pint is needed for effective control.  Do not add an adjuvant or tank mix Stinger with other pesticides as injury may occur.
fungicide: None
biological: Vetch seedlings can be difficult to remove by hand because they have a stout tap root and often break off when pulled by hand.  The broken plants are able to regrow.  Often by the time you see the vetch emerging from the crop hole there is a large vegetative mass beneath the plastic.  It is important to remove/control vetch prior to seed development in order to reduce the amount of seed going back into the seed bank for future germination.

name: Spotted wing drosophila (Drosophila suzukii)
symptoms:
SWD overwinter as adults and maybe pupae in leaf litter, duff, and rotting fruit. Adult flies live for up to 2 weeks. Females can lay 300 eggs
and egg to adult occurs in as little as 8 days. May have over 10 generations per growing season. Females lay eggs in fruit, larvae eat flesh, which renders it unmarketable or causes customer discontent (infested fruit ‘melts down’ in 2 days). Egg laying also introduces fungal pathogens, which rot fruit. Unlike other fruit flies, SWD attacks sound ripening fruit. Once eggs laid in fruit, no longer able to control with pesticides. Short lifecycle and overlapping generations make spray timing difficult. Requires sprays near harvest time and requires multiple sprays which can lead to pesticide resistance. Adapted from: http://ag.umass.edu/fruit/resources/spotted-wing-drosophila-id-biology
chemical: Many insecticides are effective on SWD, however, note resistance development issues as described below. Also, note pre-harvest intervals carefully.
fungicide: Repeated use of insecticides as necessary can favor resistance development. SWD, because of it's many generations, could develop insecticide resistance readily. Be sure to rotate insecticide mode of action as often as possible. Use no more than two back-to-back applications of the same insecticide active ingredient/mode of action. Read the label for specific resistance avoidance strategies.
biological: Monitoring is recommended to determine the need to control. Sanitation and promoting an open canopy with pruning can make conditions less favorable for SWD.

name: Cutleaf eveningprimrose (Oenothera laciniata)
symptoms: Herbaceous winter annual or biennial.
fungicide: None
biological: None

name: Hickory shuckworm: Cydia carayana (Fitch)
symptoms:
The eggs of the shuckworm are small, white and flattened in appearance.  Because of their minute size, eggs are usually not noticed until after they have hatched. After egg hatch has occurred, a chalky white deposit is usually left at the oviposition site. Upon hatching, the larvae begin to tunnel within the nut.  The immature larva is a small white caterpillar.  At maturity, larvae are about one-third to one-half inch (8 - 12 mm) in length, with a “creamy” to “dirty” white body and a reddish-brown head. The pupae, which are also found within the shuck, are initially light yellow-brown in color.  They eventually turn dark brown to black just prior to adult emergence.  Pupae are approximately one-fourth to one-third of an inch (6-8 mm) in length. 
Adult emergence beginning in late March or early April. Moths emerging in the spring, prior to nut formation, lay their eggs on pecan foliage, the galls of pecan phylloxera, and nuts of early developing hickories. Shuckworms hatching from eggs deposited on the foliage will generally die before completing their life cycle.  However, those larvae developing within the phylloxera galls or hickory nuts are able to complete their life cycle, thus maintaining the population until nut formation occurs.  Researchers have also reported that adult moths of the overwintering generation emerge from the shucks as late as July, August and September. During the summer months, female shuckworms begin to deposit their eggs on the nuts.  After nut formation occurs, shuckworms populations usually increase with each succeeding generation.  The number of generations per year will vary from two to five depending on location.
chemical: Please see "Trade Names" and "Active Ingredient" sections for recommendations.
fungicide: None.
biological: Cultural practices can also be used for reducing shuckworm infestations. Where practical, old shucks containing the overwintering larvae can be collected and destroyed. This could reduce or eliminate the need for insecticides to control this insect. The intensity of shuckworm infestations can be deceased further by reducing or eliminating those alternate hosts which provide food and shelter for the developing insect prior to nut formation.  The most important of these are the galls of the pecan stem and leaf phylloxera, and the early developing nuts of several species of hickory. Phylloxera can be controlled either with insecticides or by the planting of resistant varieties.

name: Pecan leaf scorch mite: Eotetranychus hicoriae (McGregor)
symptoms:
Females have a fuller body than the male and females are more numerous than males. Pecan leaf scorch mites are found on the underside of the leaflet where groups of mites form beneath a sparse silken interveinal web, usually starting near the mid-vein. 
During the summer, mites can complete a generation in less than two weeks under optimum conditions and the population can potentially increase 11 times each generation. Pecan leaf scorch mite populations can build up as early as June on pecan foliage.  The most damaging populations, however, occur in September and October when feeding damage can cause early defoliation. After feeding is completed in the fall, the mites migrate off the foliage onto the limbs and enter diapause.
chemical: Please see "Trade Names" and "Active Ingredient" sections for recommendations.
fungicide: None.
biological: None.

name:
Spittlebugs:
Clastoptera achatina Germar
Clastoptera obtusa (Say)
symptoms:
The adults are active hoppers and flyers with piercing-sucking type mouthparts and are characterized by two rings of spines around the hind legs.  Adults of C. obtusa are tan with brown areas on the middle of each forewing. Clastoptera achatina adults are pale green to white.  The nymphs are pale yellow to white and are wingless with a dorso-ventrally flattened body, Nymphs occur in small groups below frothy spittle masses on the current years growth.  Commonly the spittle masses are 0.5 - 2.0 cm long and often occur at the base of nut clusters.  When the last instar nymphs emerge from the spittle mass, the mass dries up. 

Two generations of spittlebug occur each season in the southeastern United States.  Second generation females lay their eggs beneath the pecan tree bark in the summer.  The eggs hatch in early May of the following year and first generation spittle masses appear soon after fruit set.  Population levels are usually low during the first generation.  Adults emerge in late-June or early July and by mid-July the second generation of spittle masses appear.  Second generation adults emerge in August and females lay the overwintering eggs.
chemical: Please see "Trade Names" and "Active Ingredient" sections for recommendations.
fungicide: None.
biological: None.

name: Pecan weevil: Curculio caryae Horn
symptoms: The pecan weevil is a light-brown or grayish beetle about 0.5 inch (12 mm) long, with a long beak.  The beak of the female is slightly longer than the body, while that of the male is about half as long as the body.  Immature larvae are white.  Mature larvae are fat, creamy-white grubs about 0.38 to 0.6 inch (9-15 mm) long, with reddish brown heads.
chemical: Please see "Trade Names" and "Active Ingredient" sections for recommendations.
fungicide: None
biological: None

name: Marssonina Leaf and Fruit Blotch, Marssonina coronaria
symptoms:
Symptoms and significance. Leaf symptoms express first as small grey to large brown round spots (blotches) that can coalesce in time, or are sometimes in a form of more dispersed smaller spots on more resistant cultivars. When the blotches enlarge, edges have typical frondy i.e. thready appearance upon closer look. First symptoms are usually visible at the end of August and beginning of September, but can be found as early as July. When leaf infections become severe due to lack of fungicide cover sprays, they lead to leaf yellowing and lower crown defoliation. Apple leaf symptoms are more prevalent then symptoms on fruit. Marssonina blotch symptoms on fruit have been found in New York repeatedly for two years (please see section "Gallery" on the menu above). Marssonina Leaf and Fruit Blotch leads to defoliation of apple trees during late summer if cover sprays with fungicides are not applied at shorter spray intervals i.e. in alignment with frequent rain events. Even though the primary host for M. coronaria is apple, other species such as Malus baccata and Chaenomeles spp. are also known as hosts of this fungus and serve as inoculum sources. M. coronaria overwinters in fallen leaves on the orchard floor. Disease symptoms are predominantly expressed on leaves and only one literature source described the Marssonina blotch symptoms on apple fruit as small dark circular lesions. Since apple fruit infections are rare these could be misdiagnosed for other causes. Marssonina fruit blotches are visible as dented dark green, brown or black round to diffuse-edge specks usually occuring after high infection pressure on leaves. These symptoms can severely reduce the fruit quality and can have delayed expression after harvest, becoming visible for the first time in storage or at a grocery store. Hence, this disease can reduce marketable yield while defoliation reduces overall vigor of apple trees. With premature tree defoliation that sometimes reaches up to 88%, developing fruit and buds are poorly supplied with photosyntesis nutrients thus threatening the next year's flowering, shoot growth and harvest in the next growing season. In addition, fruit quality and tree health on defoliated trees can be reduced by decline in storaged starch, reduced fruit coloring and by abiotic factors acting on fruit after defoliation.

Life cycle. Ascospores or conidia cause first infections in spring. Ascospores form in the overwintered cup-like fungal structures that form on the leaf litter from last year residing on the orchard floor. It is not known whether apothecia can form under the conditions in USA apple growing regions. It has been reported that in Korea apothecia do not form and that the fungus overwinters as asexual spores (conidia) on fallen leaves. Ascospores cause for primary infections, while conidia are asexual spores cause secondary infections. Conidia are produced in acervuli and can serve as primary infection spores in the lack of ascospores. Acervuli are plate-like spore groups visible as small round specks in typical Marssonina blotches after leaf epidermis is ruptured by the pushing spore masses. Conidia can cause several secondary infections during the season. To express as blotch, leaf infections require extended period of moisture i.e. leaf wetness, high relative air humidity and temperatures between 20 to 25°C. It seems that in Europe and probably in contintntal regions of the US as well, infections start sometimes at the end of May through first or second week of June. Typical symptoms are usually visible 40 to 45 days after the infection. In the orchard, spores are disseminated by rain and wind. Trade with nursery material that bears infected leaves allows introduction of this disease in new distant regions. Since apple fruit are rarely infected, introduction by infected fruit into new orchards or regions is probably of low risk but this might change in the future with increaseing trade and demand of organic apples.
chemical:
Conventional apple production. Currently, there are no labelled fungicides for control of Marssonina Leaf and Fruit Blotch on apple in the USA. Various researchers indicate that thiophanate-methyl (Topsin-M), DMI fungicides such as Inspire Super (contains difenoconazole, Frac group 3), QoI trifloxystrobin (Flint), and Merivon which combines an SDHI fungicide fluxapyroxad (FRAC group 7) and QoI pyraclostrobin (FRAC Group 11), are effective against Marssonina fungal species on apple and/or poplar. However, none of these fungicides have labelled use for M. coronaria on apples so far in the USA. EBDC fungicides such as mancozeb (Manzate) or metiram (Polyram) are effective but have no labelled use for this disease of apple in the USA and are of very limited utility due to limitation of 77 days pre-harvest interval (PHI). Recent study from China has showed that DMI-s such as tebuconazole, hexaconazole, propiconazole, alone or DMI tebuconazole + benziothiazolinone (from a group of isothiazolinones) were very effective when applied at 20-day intervals, from early July to late August. The same study reports that Bordeaux mix + tebuconazole, Bordeaux mix + propiconazole, or Bordeaux mix + tebuconazole + benziothiazolinone alternated at 25 days were very effective. Except Bordeaux mix, none of these fungicide have label for use on apples in USA orchards. In general, Marssonina has low sensitivity to copper fungicides. Other fungicides used in other countries for control of this fungus are carbendazim (benzimidazol, FRAC group 1), a QoI kresoxim-methyl, and DMI-s flusilazol and prochloraz. However, none of these fungicides have current labels for use on apples except Sovran (kresoxim-methyl), but which is not labelled for M. coronaria use.

Organig apple production. In organic apple production where this pathogen can have a devastating impact on both tree weakening and fruit quality, it is essential to prune the tree crown to facilitate good air circulation and to eliminate leaf litter as the major infection source (see "Non Chemical Control" section below). Recent study from Germany shows that in organic orchards 10 to 12 sprays per year of each of the following products: acid clay Myco-Sin, Myco-Sin + sulfur, Funguran (copper hydroxide), Curatio (lime sulfur) or sulfur alone provide relatively good control if the first spray application is started around 10 to 12 June. These treatments allowed only 4-15% of MLB incidence in 2017 and 5-25% in 2018 efficacy trials.

Marssonina coronaria infection prediction. To better time fungicide spray applications for maximum efficacy in MLB control in both conventional and organic orchards, use of RIMpro’s Marssonina prediction model that is based on up to 10-day weather forecast is highly recommended and especially helpful in orchards that had severe MLB outbreaks in the past (RIMpro B.V., Zoelmond, Netherlands). More information about this model and subscription can be found here: https://www.rimpro.eu/faces/index.xhtml?faces-redirect=true by clicking on the button “Create a new RIMpro account.”
fungicide: The main problems with all the above mentioned single-site fungicides is significant potential for loss of their efficacy due to development of fungicide resistance in M. coronaria populations and unacceptable accumulation of residues on fruit. Resisatnce in M. coronaria to thiophanate-methyl has been reported in Japan.
biological:
In apple orchards where this pathogen had caused fruit losses or tree weakening by defoliation, it is essential to prune the tree crown to facilitate good air circulation and to eliminate leaf litter as the major infection source. Hence, the same recommendations to reduce overwintering inoculum of apple scab fungus by degrading leaf litter would help for Marssonina Leaf and Fruit Blotch. If you had a high incidence of this disease, you should reduce inoculum size by promoting biological processes of degradation of leaves in fall, spring, or both in fall and spring. The aim of this practice is to quicken the degradation of leaf litter by promoting the activity of microorganisms and worms on and in the soil. In conventional orchards, spray apple leaves on the tree with urea just 1 to 2 days before the major leaf drop in fall or winter (first severe frost) or as leaf litter on the orchard floor. When leaves are on the branches you will have better coverage with urea. Make sure this practice is done late enough in fall and start of winter to avoid promoting any late growth with sprayed nitrogen. If spraying leaf litter on the ground, the best time to apply urea is late winter but before bud break. Turn air deflectors of your air-blast sprayer downward and/or turn off top nozzles to allow spray mist to lift loose leaves and coat them with urea. Use rate of 40 lbs of urea per acre in 100 gallons of water. Once done, you must wash and rinse well your spray equipment since urea can wear up any rubber parts, washers and gaskets in the sprayer, especially the pump diaphragm.

In organic apple orchards urea is not allowed. When ground is without snow cover and it is not muddy, use flail mower in organic orchards to shred the fallen leaves to smaller peaces instead. This method can also be used in conventional apple orchards. If practical, rake leaves into row middles from under the trees and remove leaf piles with flail mower mode for scalping the sod. Instead of urea, lime can be applied in both organic and conventional orchards at a rate of 2.5 tons/A. If lime is used, it is better to apply it after the leaf drop in fall or early in the winter. Lime increases pH or basicity of yhe soil, thus promoting microbial activity and litter breakdown. Reduction of M.coronaria inoculum with the above specified practices does not mean you do not need to spray against this disease next summer. Enough inoculum can always be present in the orchard to cause infection. However, inoculum reduction secures the better efficacy of your fungicide sprays and reduces the overall chance for severe M. coronaria infections.

name: Plum curculio (Conotrachelus nenuphar)
symptoms:
Biology
Plum curculio (PC) is a snout-nosed beetle, aka a weevil. The adult is small, about 1/4 inch, mottled black, grey and brown. When handled it will often drop and “play dead”.

The larva is a whitish, legless grub, and its feeding in fruitlets causes premature drop. Larvae then crawl out of fallen fruitlets into the soil and pupate. Adults emerge from the soil after ~16 days and feed within and outside of orchards until cold weather drives them into hibernating spots.

Generally, commercial orchards do not have overwintering populations within their borders. Some studies, however, have shown that PCs can overwinter inside orchard blocks that are weedy in the fall.  Wild hosts (abandoned orchards, crab apples, etc.) near orchards provide habitat which allows adult PC to migrate into orchards before and after bloom.

Monitoring
Fruitlets should be monitored beginning at about 5 mm diameter along orchard borders to determine if new injury is occuring. If fresh oviposition scars are observed, a first cover spray should be made to the entire block. Cool, wet weather will prolong PC activity. Continue to monitor for fresh scars. If more are found, a second cover spray targeting perimeter-row trees may be needed.

Because PC immigration and oviposition period is affected by weather patterns after Petal Fall, insecticide coverage should be maintained until 308 DD (base 50F) from Petal Fall.

A monitoring system that makes use of attractive lures, termed the ‘trap tree’ approach, has been developed. It involves baiting the branches of one perimeter-row tree with a synergistic two-component lure comprised of benzaldehyde, one synthetic component of flowers and developing fruit, in association with grandisoic acid, the synthetic PC pheromone. By examining the fruit solely on the odor-baited tree for signs of fresh PC injury this monitoring technique has proven effective at determining, on a timely manner, whether perimeter-row insecticide sprays are required against PC after the whole-block petal fall spray. Lures are commercially available and last for the entire PC oviposition period.

Adapted from https://netreefruit.org/apples/insects/plum-curculio-pc
chemical:
Management of PC relies heavily on petal fall, first and second cover insecticide applications. The first insecticide application should be made to the whole orchard in order to control PC that have migrated into the inner part of the orchard.

Additional insecticide applications may be necessary and can be limited to the outer two rows of trees.
Kaolin clay (Surround WP) is an OMRI-listed material that can also be complementary to conventional management strategies. Applied in suspension in water, kaolin clay produces a dry white film layer of interlocking microscopic particles on the surface of leaves, stems, and fruit after evaporation of the water. Kaolin acts as a physical barrier preventing insects from reaching vulnerable plant tissue. It acts as a repellent by creating an unsuitable surface for feeding or egg-laying.

Surround applications begin at Petal Fall and get reapplied weekly to maintain coverage and deter egg-laying. 

Do not apply insecticides until bloom is completely finished to reduce unwanted pollinator exposure to insecticides.

Adapted from: https://netreefruit.org/apples/insects/plum-curculio-pc
fungicide: Other than following label directions for insecticide mode of action (IRAC #) no specific resistance issues noted.
biological: None.

name: Botryosphaeria canker and dieback; Botryosphaeriaceae spp.
symptoms:
-Symptoms and Signs.
Multiple species of fungi within the Botryosphaeriaceae family are known to be pathogenic to grapevines and able to initiate Botryosphaeria canker. Infected trunks or cordons display cankers, which are characterized by wedged-shaped regions of discoloration and necrosis from a cross-sectional view. The canker formation of Botryosphaeria is similar to other trunk pathogens like Eutypa lata. However, unlike other common trunk diseases, there is no clear foliar symptoms of Botryosphaeria canker infection. Instead, the shoots and leaves directly above the canker will completely die over the course of the growing season. The cankers have a severe girdling effect on vasculature above the site of infection on the trunk or cordon.
 
-Disease cycle.
The fungus is able to survive through winter in the form of pycnidia, which are dark structures that appear on the exterior of diseased plant material. The pycnidia structures are able to constantly produce spores that are sufficient to cause infection. Mediated by rain and wet conditions, the spores are dispersed throughout the vineyard during the growing season. Host invasion and subsequent infections occur at the site of wounds, many of which are made during pruning and other injurious practices. Once in contact with freshly wounded wood, spores are able to germinate in the vine’s vessel elements and induce the signs of disease including canker formation and dieback.
biological:
New mechanical wounds may contribute to the spread of the infection. Thus, limiting the number of wounds incurred during cultural practices is an effective method for reducing disease transmission. It is important to properly dispose of all diseased plant material from the vineyard as pycnidia are able to persist on their surfaces and produce spores that can infect healthy vines.
·       Excise all infected plant material by pruning well below the canker.
·       Make angled cuts to allow all wounded surfaces to drain properly.
·       Limit pruning during wet periods in the spring when the fungus is more likely sporulating.
·       Prune late in the season when spore production is less abundant and the wounds are less susceptible to infection.
Infection of grapevines by Botryosphaeriaceae spp. is permanent and accompanied with symptoms that cannot be resolved using fungicide or other chemical treatments.

name: Eutypa Dieback; Eutypa lata
symptoms:
-Symptoms and Signs.
Infection by Eutypa lata can be identified through an examination of the main trunk of the vine for cankers. Flattened and darkly discolored areas around the trunk are characteristic of canker formation. Frequently, older bark may limit the visibility of symptoms, so cross-sectional cuts along the trunk are necessary for proper diagnosis. In addition to symptoms observed on the main trunk of the vine, leaf and shoot symptoms are easily detected. During the spring, growth directly above the diseased area of the trunk may yield stunted vasculature with the leaves developing abnormal cupped shape and yellowed coloration. Despite these symptoms, the growth above the canker will appear to recover later in the year. However, the area above the cankers on the trunk will eventually die as a result of the infection.
 
-Disease cycle.   
The primary mode of infection of E. lata is entry through wounds resulting from pruning. The spread of the fungus is mediated by the production of spores in the presence of water. Wet conditions from rain and overhead irrigation promote the dispersion of the spores and increase the likelihood of contact with susceptible plant tissue. Once in contact with a fresh wound, the spores are able to germinate in the vessel elements of the vine. It is important to note that wounds become less susceptible to infection as they age and may become resistant between two to four weeks after the initial wounding event. Germination of the spores is followed by fungal body growth and canker formation at the site of infection.
biological:
Altering cultural practices to avoid periods of rain and high sporulation can serve as effective non-chemical controls of the pathogen. In order to prevent future infection of other vines, diseased material should be removed from the vineyard. It is important to cut the vine at least 2 inches below the canker and properly dispose of the material through burial or burning. If left in the vineyard, diseased trunks can allow for continued spore production and further spread of the fungal infection. 
·      Avoid pruning before and during wet weather.
·      Use drip irrigation to limit spore dispersal.
·      Watch for symptoms of infection in the shoots and leaves in early spring.
·      Remove all infected plant material from the vineyard to limit future transmission.

name: Phomopsis Dieback; Phomopsis viticola
symptoms:
-Symptoms and Signs.
Phomopsis dieback is caused by an infection of Phomopsis viticola in grapevine trunks and cordons. The disease is most commonly characterized by canker formation, a wedge-shaped region of discoloration in the trunk, which can be clearly observed through a cross-sectional view. The region of dark discoloration is composed of necrotic woody tissue. The death of tissue in the trunk of the vine results in a girdling effect that decreases both vigor and yield as the disease progresses. 
 
-Disease Cycle.
P. viticola is able to survive through the harsh winter months in the form of pycnidia structures. These structures appear as small black spots on the exterior of old diseased plant material and are able to produce spores. During wet weather, the spores are released and dispersed throughout the vineyard by rain splashing. If the spores come in contact with recently cut wounds in the grapevine trunks, they are able to germinate inside vessel elements and initiate infection. In addition, the infection of foliage may occur if the spores come in contact with young green tissue during multiple days of moist and cool weather.
biological:
The dieback disease associated with P. viticola infection in the trunk of the grapevine is permanent and cannot be resolved through fungicide treatment. However, non-chemical control methods are effective at limiting the frequency of the infection and preventing disease transmission to other healthy vines in the vineyard.
·      Select proper sites with well-drained soil and direct sunlight to reduce the duration of wet periods.
·      Limit pruning before and during wet weather as water facilitates the dispersal of spores.
·      Avoid unnecessary injurious practices to limit pathogen entry through wounds.
·      Remove all diseased plant material from the vineyard as the fungal pathogen is able to produce spores for years on dead wood.

name: Esca (Measles); Phaeoacremonium spp.
symptoms:
-Symptoms and Signs.
Esca is thought to be caused by a complex of multiple fungal species. The disease is most commonly attributed to Phaeoacremonium aleophilum and Phaeomoniella chlamydospora. Esca infections have very distinct symptoms that manifest in both the foliage and trunks of grapevines. Younger vines infected with the pathogenic fungi will show indications of reduced vigor as well as decreased foliage and leaf size. In addition, the foliar symptoms caused by infection include interveinal leaf necrosis that appears red or yellow depending on the grapevine cultivar. Frequently, the leaves will prematurely drop from the shoots and result in shoot tip dieback. Cuts through the cordon or trunk of infected vines will expose darkened rings. These markings are the result of phenolic deposits that block vessel elements in response to the wounding as a defense mechanism. The limitation of flow leads to the death of shoots directly above infected areas of the grapevine trunk.
 
-Disease Cycle.
The fungal pathogens that are responsible for Esca produce perithecia, which are small black structures that allow the pathogen to persist on infected plant material through the winter. The perithecia then are able to produce and release spores during rainfall and other wet conditions. The water allows for greater dispersal of the spores which increases their ability to come in contact with vulnerable wounds in the grapevine from pruning or other cultural practices. Once in contact with a fresh wound, the spores are able to germinate inside the vessel elements of the vine, produce fungal bodies, and initiate infection. Thus, the removal of all infected material from the vineyard is vital as it may harbor spore producing structures that can infect other healthy vines.
biological:
Cultural control methods include the limitation of injurious practices that provide entry of the pathogen leading to subsequent infection. If pruning during wet weather is necessary, it is recommended to use the strategy of double pruning. During this practice, the first cut is made inches longer than normal. Next, during dry conditions which are less conducive for the pathogen’s spread, a second cut is made at the appropriate location. This practice minimizes the risk of infection by removing any material that may have come in contact with fungal spores in the first wound.
·      Avoid pruning during wet conditions which help facilitate the spread of the pathogen.
·      Practice double pruning if cuts must be made during unfavorably wet weather conditions.
·      Excise all infected plant material from the vine.
·      Remove all diseased plant material from the vineyard to prevent future infection.

name: Crown Gall; Agrobacterium vitis
symptoms:
-Symptoms and Signs. 
A clear indication of Agrobacterium vitis infection is the development of irregular swelling growths called galls. The galls most commonly appear near the graft union, but they can also occur on other sites of damage. The rapid cellular expansion associated with gall formation leads to the production of soft white tissue in new growths and flakey, cork-like tissue in older growths. Galls may cause a reduction in nutrient and water flow, which leads to decreased vigor and yield in established vines while causing death in younger vines.
 
-Disease cycle.
Infection of a healthy grape vine starts at the location of injury caused by the grafting process, exposure to freezing temperatures, and other wounds incurred during cultural practices. Plant cells damaged during the injury event release compounds that normally regulate repair. However, these same compounds are recognized by A. vitis and direct the bacterium to the site of injury, where it is able to inject its genetic material into susceptible plant cells. This causes a change in the production of plant hormones, which trigger local physiological changes and gall production. Grapevines infected with A. vitis may display symptoms of the infection or remain asymptomatic until environmental conditions are ideal for further progression of the disease.
biological:
Frequently, the addition of soil containing infested grape vine debris is responsible for A. vitis introduction. A. vitis is able to survive on root or grape debris in the soil for years after the removal of infected vines. Successful disposal of infected plant material can limit the pathogen’s ability to persist in the soil and prevent future infections. Despite the presence of the pathogen in the soil, in many cases, effective control measures can still be employed to reduce disease incidence rates.
·    Limit unnecessary injurious practices to help prevent transmission since A. vitis infection is facilitated by entry through wounds.
·    Ensure proper site selection to lower the risk of damage caused by freeze injury since low areas of high moisture and heavy soil are conducive for frost.
·    Avoid over-cropping to help ensure adequate vine acclimation to cold conditions. 
·    Mound soil over the graft union in the fall to insulate the vine and reduce freezing damage.
·    Plant on rootstocks which have been reported to be more tolerant or resistant to crown gall disease.
